Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Story: I sat at my desk, laptop open, half-listening to the hum of my project team on the video call. My manager was asking for time estimates on the new feature, and I knew I needed to chime in soon. The planning session was informal, but everyone expected me to give a realistic timeline. My phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Can you call when you have a minute? Dad seems a bit down today.” I glanced at the clock. If I called now, I’d miss my chance to speak up in the meeting, but if I waited, I’d be letting my parents down when they needed me. I could hear the expectation in my mom’s words—she wanted me to check in, to be the daughter who noticed when things weren’t right at home. At the same time, my team was waiting for my input, trusting me to help shape the project’s direction. My heart pounded as I weighed the pull of both worlds, feeling the pressure of being needed in two places at once.
